{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox artist | name = Azlan McLennan | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1975}} | birth_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Australian | known_for = [[Visual art]] | education = [[Victorian College of the Arts]] in [[Melbourne]]. | movement = [[Anti-art]], [[Political satire]] | notable_works = | patrons = | influenced by = [[Marxism]] | influenced = | awards = }}
'''Azlan McLennan''' (born 1975 in the United States)<ref name="Art labels">[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,18507141-2702,00.html "Art labels Howard a terrorist"] ''The Australian,'' 18 March 2006. Accessed 1 May 2008</ref> is a visual artist and socialist activist based in [[Melbourne]], Australia.<ref>[http://www.sa.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1984&Itemid=106 "Trotsky vs Stalin: Azlan McLennan"] ''Socialist Alternative,'' Edition 141, May 2009. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref> He is a graduate of the [[Victorian College of the Arts]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110728000321/http://savevca.org/vca/alumni "Alumni of the V.C.A."] ''Save the VCA''. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref> His art is known for its political content and has been the subject of considerable debate and media attention in Australia.<ref>[http://www.visualarts.net.au/files/NAVAQuarterly(segment).pdf "Artist Profile: Azlan McLennan"] ''NAVA Quarterly''. December 2005. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref>
== Art == [[File:Proudly UnAustralian.jpg|thumb|250px|right|''Proudly UnAustralian'' by Azlan McLennan, confiscated by the Victoria Police in Melbourne, 2006.]] Conceptually, McLennan's work tends to be unambiguous and antagonistic from a left-wing perspective, loosely following the traditions of [[agitprop]], [[anti-art]] and [[Institutional Critique]], incorporating elements of [[détournement]], [[readymade]] or [[installation art|installation]]. His works have often been characterised as controversial by conservative politicians, journalists and art critics, usually portraying the artist in a negative light.<ref name="The politics">[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/05/13/1084289821310.html "The politics of art"] ''The Age,'' 14 May 2004. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> Alternatively, various liberal lawyers, academics and activists have defended his works, usually on the basis of [[free speech]], due to the offence sometimes caused by his art for its often overt left-leaning bias.<ref>[http://www.visualarts.net.au/files/NQ%20Dec%2008_fin.pdf "25 Years: NAVA at the forefront of Australia’s cultural policy agenda"] ''NAVA Quarterly''. December 2008. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref> The artist has expressed public criticisms over [[Zionism]], the [[War on Terror]], [[Australian nationalism]] and racism, the [[Mandatory detention in Australia|mandatory detention]] of [[asylum seekers]], various political figures and the [[managerial class]] of the [[art world]].<ref>[http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:WhLNCpl6XgEJ:www.visualarts.net.au/files/Art_Censorship.pdf "Dealing With Art Censorship"]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''National Association for the Visual Arts'' Media Release, 30 March 2009. Accessed 20 April 2009</ref>
McLennan has cited the artists [[John Heartfield]]<ref name="Azlan">[http://artabase.net/artist/820-azlan-mclennan Azlan McLennan] ''Artabase''. Accessed 10 July 2009</ref> and [[Leon Kuhn]]<ref name="left">[http://redflag.org.au/article/left-loses-inspiring-artist-and-comrade The Left loses an inspiring artist and comrade] ''Red Flag'', 31 December 2013. Accessed 3 January 2014</ref> as influences. He has work in collections of the [[National Gallery of Australia]]<ref name="Azlan" /> and the [[National Library of Australia]].<ref>[http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/5057674 "Be young & shut up"] ''National Library of Australia''. Accessed 4 November 2013</ref>
== Political affiliations == McLennan is a member of the [[Trotskyism|Trotskyist]] organisation [[Socialist Alternative (Australia)|Socialist Alternative]].<ref name="Connex">[http://www.sa.org.au/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=5976:connex-tries-to-censor-pro-palestinian-art "Connex tries to censor pro-Palestinian art"] ''Socialist Alternative,'' 11 March 2009. Accessed 24 May 2009</ref> Previously, he has been associated with the [[Socialist Alliance (Australia)|Socialist Alliance]],<ref>[http://www.melbourne-palestine.info/resources/ageunholyalliance.htm "Zionism and imperialism: an unholy alliance"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010095232/http://www.melbourne-palestine.info/resources/ageunholyalliance.htm |date=10 October 2007 }} ''Melbourne Palestine Solidarity Network,'' 9 August 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> the [[Stop the War Coalition (Australia)|Stop the War Coalition]],<ref>[http://azlanmclennan.com/?page_id=312 "Propaganda"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314052529/http://azlanmclennan.com/?page_id=312 |date=14 March 2009 }} ''Azlan McLennan'' website. Accessed 25 January 2009</ref> [[Students for Palestine]],<ref>[https://archive.is/20130415225029/http://www.studentsforpalestine.org/?p=314 "Artists Support Boycott Israel 19"] ''Students for Palestine,'' 18 August 2011. Accessed 24 April 2012</ref> the [[Refugee Action Collective (Victoria)|Refugee Action Collective]],<ref>[http://redpenzine.wordpress.com/ The Red Pen Zine] ''The Red Pen''. Accessed 16 November 2010</ref> the [[University of Melbourne Graduate Student Association]],<ref>[http://www.gsa.unimelb.edu.au/elections/Annual_Graduate_Student_Elections_2009.shtml "Annual Graduate Student Elections 2009"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100223053959/http://www.gsa.unimelb.edu.au/elections/Annual_Graduate_Student_Elections_2009.shtml |date=23 February 2010 }} ''University of Melbourne Graduate Student Association,'' 15 August. 2009. Accessed 27 January 2010</ref> the [[Victorian College of the Arts Student Union]]<ref>[http://www.sa.org.au/component/content/article/194-edition-145/2086-vca-students-fight-job-and-course-cuts VCA students fight job and course cuts]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''Socialist Alternative,'' Edition 145, September 2009. Accessed 12 June 2010</ref> and the [[United Voice]] trade union.<ref>[http://menasolidaritynetwork.com/2011/05/30/egypt-hossam-el-hamalawy-and-reem-maged-called-before-military-judges/ Egypt: Hossam el-Hamalawy and Reem Maged called before military judges] ''MENA Solidarity Network,'' 30 May 2011. Accessed 7 January 2014</ref> He regularly produces posters for the Australian [[Far-left politics|far left's]] various political demonstrations and meetings.<ref name="Azlan" /> He has written articles for the publications of both Socialist Alternative and the Socialist Alliance.<ref name="left" /><ref name="Connex" />
== Controversy ==
=== Victorian College of the Arts === In August 2003, McLennan hired a [[G4S|Group 4 Securicor]] guard to keep gallery punters out of an exhibition opening at the VCA. Group 4 run [[immigration detention]] centres in Australia, such as [[Baxter Immigration Reception and Processing Centre|Baxter Detention Centre]] and the now closed [[Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre|Woomera Detention Centre]]. The security guard was reportedly humiliated due to the incident which occurred at a time of high criticism of the [[John Howard]] government's treatment of [[Refugee#Asylum seekers|asylum seekers]].<ref>[https://archive.is/20121209182233/http://www.theage.com.au/cgi-bin/common/popupPrintArticle.pl?path=/articles/2003/09/03/1062548903857.html "VCA artwork raises ethics concerns"] ''The Age,'' 4 September 2003. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref>
=== 24seven === In May 2004, McLennan produced ''Fifty-six,'' an exhibition designed to coincide with [[Nakba Day]], the title drawing on the number of years since the establishment of [[Israel]]. The public exhibition in the shop front window space of 24seven Gallery on one of Melbourne CBD's busy streets, was censored by the [[City of Melbourne]] days after it was installed. The installation consisted of a large wall painting of an Israeli flag, with "debatable" statistics on the gallery's window about Israel's treatment of Palestinians. The scandal made international news, many pro-Israel individuals and groups accusing McLennan of [[antisemitism]]. This put a number of Victorian political figures such as former Premier [[Steve Bracks]], Lord Mayor [[John So]] and former City of Melbourne councillor Kimberly Kitching under pressure to respond. The use of taxpayer's money to fund the space fuelled a lot of the debate.<ref>[http://gallery.discoverymedia.com.au/artzinePub/story.asp?id=375&section=ExNews "Making Space – spanking the hand that feeds it"] ''Art Right Now,'' 16 June 2007. Accessed 22 May 2009</ref> McLennan also deeply outraged some critics by insinuating that the [[Nazis]] had a similar position on what they termed [[degenerate art]]. McLennan maintains a strong criticism of Israeli policies.<ref name="The politics" />
=== Citylights === In August 2004, McLennan displayed ''State Sponsored'', a collection of portraits of [[Hamas]] militants, including [[Sheikh Ahmed Yassin]] and [[Abdul Aziz Rantisi|Dr. Abdul Aziz Rantisi]] and the dates they were assassinated. The work was exhibited at Citylights project – a public art space in a Melbourne CBD lane way. McLennan was accused of glorifying terrorism by Ted Lapkin, a senior policy analyst of the [[Australia/Israel & Jewish Affairs Council]]. Andrew Mac, Citylights' curator and director defended the work on the grounds of diversity of opinion stating the artist's use of "state sponsored" referred to [[state terrorism]].<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Jewish-group-blasts-offensive-artwork/2004/12/10/1102625519852.html "Jewish group blasts 'offensive' artwork"] ''The Age,'' 10 December 2004. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref>
=== Platform Artists Group === In September 2005, the City of Melbourne intervened to terminate McLennan's ''Canberra's 18'' exhibition shortly before it was scheduled to be shown at the [[Platform artists group]]'s [[Artist-run initiative]] (ARI), Platform 2. The exhibition was to include images of the then 18 Islamic organisations proscribed as terrorists by the Australian Government and the basis for their formation. City of Melbourne Deputy Mayor [[Gary Singer]] claimed the proper guidelines were not followed. Human rights campaigner and barrister [[Julian Burnside]] claimed the censorship was about governments testing how much Australians would tolerate such occurrences.<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/war-on-terrorism-is-claiming-victims-on-the-walls-of-art-galleries/2005/09/15/1126750082623.html "War on terrorism is claiming victims on the walls of art galleries"] ''Sydney Morning Herald,'' 16 September 2005. Accessed 3 May 2008</ref> McLennan accused City of Melbourne of political censorship and appeasing Zionists.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2005/09/14/1126377376345.html "City council bans 'terror artwork'"] ''The Age,'' 15 September 2005. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> Singer's areas of special interests ironically include [[civil liberties]].<ref>[http://www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/info.cfm?top=190&pa=1317&pg=1996 "Deputy Lord Mayor Gary Singer"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725155111/http://www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/info.cfm?top=190&pa=1317&pg=1996 |date=25 July 2008 }} ''City of Melbourne,'' Accessed 3 May 2008</ref>
=== Monash University === [[Monash University Art and Design Faculty]] in Melbourne withdrew McLennan's video ''Mind the Gap'' in October 2005, ironically made for the same exhibition Monash had agreed to show the censored ''Canberra's 18'' work. The video contained graphic footage of the [[beheading]] of British contractor [[Kenneth Bigley]] by [[Jama'at al-Tawhid wal-Jihad|Tawhid and Jihad]] in 2004. The video criticised former British Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] for his role in the Iraq war.<ref>[http://www.unmagazine.org/un7.html "Azlan McLennan"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080520005543/http://www.unmagazine.org/un7.html |date=20 May 2008 }} ''un Magazine,'' Volume 7, 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> The censorship is likely to have been motivated by the [[Australian Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005]], particularly the controversial return to the crime of [[sedition]] introduced by the Howard government some weeks later and passed into law the following month; a move highly unpopular amongst the arts sector.<ref>[http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=71006 "Artists 'at risk' under terror laws"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060627104653/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=71006 |date=27 June 2006 }} ''NineMSN,'' 8 November 2005. Accessed 29 April 2008</ref>
=== Urban Art === City of Melbourne and acting Transport Minister [[Bob Cameron (Victorian politician)|Bob Cameron]] censored ''Pay Your Way'' in January 2006 while McLennan was in residency in Indonesia. The posters – part of the Urbanart ARI program – were displayed in public tram shelters and pulled down only hours later due to complaints. The works featured images of [[Jean Charles de Menezes]], a Brazilian man shot dead by London police and accused Muslim terrorist, [[Joseph T. Thomas|Jack Thomas]].<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/fare-game-shelters-feel-the-brush-of-protest/2006/01/09/1136771500463.html "Fare game! Shelters feel the brush of protest"] ''The Age,'' 10 January 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> The works were characterised as racist and [[Islamophobic]],<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,17795788-2862,00.html "My art is not racist"] ''Herald Sun,'' 12 January 2006. Accessed 24 May 2009</ref> yet McLennan claimed the works were satirising the post [[9-11]] racism and Islamophobia perpetuated by pro-US governments. McLennan is also a [[Muslim]] himself.<ref>[http://www.sa.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=266&Itemid=106 "Political art meets a paranoid state"] ''Socialist Alternative,'' Edition 99, February 2006. Accessed 25 April 2008</ref> Thomas' lawyer, [[Rob Stary]] attacked the work for jeopardising the trial<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/public-art-threatens-fair-trial-thomas-lawyer/2006/01/11/1136956241052.html "Public art threatens fair trial: Thomas lawyer"] ''The Age,'' 12 January 2006. Accessed 24 May 2009</ref> yet weeks later would defend McLennan publicly against the [[Footscray, Victoria|Footscray]] police.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/defiant-artist-flies-his-unaustralian-flag-again/2006/02/28/1141095741391.html "Defiant artist flies his 'UnAustralian' flag again"] ''The Age,'' 1 March 2006. Accessed 24 May 2009</ref>
=== Trocadero Art Space === Only weeks after the ''Pay Your Way'' affair, McLennan's ''Proudly UnAustralian'' was removed by the [[Victoria Police]] in Melbourne. The exhibition – featuring a burnt Australian flag – took place at Trocadero Art Space who rents a public billboard to exhibiting artists. It was to coincide with the 2006 [[Australia Day]] in January. The work was removed some days prior this date and McLennan arrived back in Australia days later to a media furore. The scandal had been criticised as offensive by those such as Federal [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] MP [[Bronwyn Bishop]] who attempted to introduce a ban on [[Flag desecration|flag burning]], and the national president of the [[Returned and Services League of Australia|Returned and Services League]]. [[Free speech]] advocates such as the [[National Association for the Visual Arts]] and criminal defence lawyer Rob Stary denounced the police's actions as an attack on [[civil rights]]. This took place only a few short months after the [[2005 Cronulla riots]] and fuelled the broader debate about [[racism in Australia]].<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2006/s1563582.htm "Art prompts call for flag-burning law change"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060211040610/http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2006/s1563582.htm |date=11 February 2006 }} ''The 7.30 Report'' (Transcript), 6 February 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref>
=== Australian Centre for Contemporary Art === McLennan wrote an article in 2006 criticising the Artistic Director of the [[Australian Centre for Contemporary Art]] (ACCA), Juliana Engberg over her reaction to artist and VCA student, Ash Keating and his appropriation of ACCA's waste disposal for the use of his art. The Engberg/Keating scandal became widely known amongst Melbourne art circles from the ACCA exhibition opening where it took place and later through the independent electronic magazine [[Crikey]]. McLennan's polemic further fuelled debate over Engberg's credentials.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/arts/power-of-one/2006/08/31/1156817027357.html "Power of one"] ''The Age,'' 1 September 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref>
=== Anna Schwartz Gallery === McLennan featured in ''Rules of Engagement'' at Melbourne ARI West Space in May 2007, which dealt with "relationships, power and exchange within the art system" according to the show's curator Mark Feary.<ref>[http://www.westspace.org.au/projects/rules-of-engagement.html?Itemid=0 "Rules of Engagement"] ''West Space'' (Catalogue Essay), May 2006. Accessed 27 April 2008</ref> McLennan's contribution, ''Art in a Capitalist Society'' depicted an authoritative picture of leading private Australian gallerist Anna Schwartz, linked to a quote about [[Exploitation of labour|exploitation]] from the [[Karl Marx]] treatise ''[[Das Kapital]]''. Schwartz has previously criticised McLennan<ref name="The politics" /> and some have accused McLennan of taking revenge.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/arts/artists-dish-it-out-to-the-dealers/2007/06/14/1181414455138.html "Artists dish it out to the dealers"] ''The Age,'' 15 June 2007. Accessed 25 April 2008</ref>
=== University of Melbourne === In a July 2009, ''[[Farrago (newspaper)|Farrago]]'' interview, McLennan attacked the [[University of Melbourne]] over the merger with the [[Victorian College of the Arts]], the [[Melbourne Model]], the liquidation of the [[Victorian College of the Arts Student Union|VCA Student Union]] and likened the Vice-chancellor, [[Glyn Davis]]' perceived political censorship to [[Adolf Hitler]]'s use of [[Nazi art|Fascist Art]] and [[Joseph Stalin]]'s use of [[Socialist Realism]]. He also depicted Davis and the Provost, [[Peter McPhee (academic)|Peter McPhee]], as [[Sex Pistols]] musicians, [[Johnny Rotten]] and [[Sid Vicious]] in a parody of the [[Sex Pistols#Never Mind the Bollocks|Never Mind the Bollocks]] album cover as well as depicting Davis as the violent [[psychopath]], [[Alex DeLarge]] in [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s film adaptation of [[A Clockwork Orange (film)|A Clockwork Orange]].<ref>"Report on the death of the VCA" ''Farrago,'' Edition 5, July 2009, p. 28–29.</ref> McLennan had previously attacked Davis and the university administration as the former General Secretary of the VCA Student Union.<ref>[http://www.sa.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1659&Itemid=106 Smashing jobs, courses and student unions: A 2020 vision?] ''Socialist Alternative,'' Edition 128, May 2008. Accessed 28 July 2009</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Chantal Akerman | image = Chantal Akerman - video still (cropped).jpg | imagesize = 225px | alt = | caption = Chantal Akerman in 2012 | birth_name = Chantal Anne Akerman | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1950|6|6}} | birth_place = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2015|10|05|df=yes|1950|6|6}} | death_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] | death_cause = [[Suicide]] | nationality = Belgian | occupation = Film director, screenwriter, artist, and film professor | years_active = 1968{{ndash}}2015 | known_for = | notable_works = ''[[Jeanne Dielman, 23 quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles]]'' }} '''Chantal Anne Akerman''' ({{IPA-fr|akɛʁman|lang}}; 6 June 1950{{spaced ndash}}5 October 2015) was a Belgian [[film director]], [[screenwriter]], [[artist]], and [[Film studies|film professor]] at the [[City College of New York]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/07/arts/chantal-akerman-belgian-filmmaker-dies-65.html|title=Chantal Akerman, Whose Films Examined Women's Inner Lives, Dies at 65|website=The New York Times}}</ref> She is best known for her three hour [[magnum opus|''magnum opus'']] ''[[Jeanne Dielman, 23 quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles]]'' (1975), which was dubbed a "masterpiece" by ''[[The New York Times]]''. According to film scholar [[Gwendolyn Audrey Foster]], Akerman's influence on [[Feminism|feminist]] filmmaking and [[avant-garde]] cinema has been substantial.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Foster |editor1-first=Gwendolyn Audrey |editor1-link=Gwendolyn Audrey Foster |date=2003 |title=Identity and Memory: The Films of Chantal Akerman |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lULjtguX9HkC&pg=PA204 |publisher=SIU Press |page=204 |isbn=978-0809325139}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Akerman was born in [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] to [[Holocaust]] survivors from [[Poland]].<ref name=nytobit /> She was the older sister of Sylviane Akerman, her only sibling. Her mother Natalia (Nelly) had survived years at [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]], where her own parents had died.<ref>{{cite web|title = Chantal Akerman obituary|url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/oct/08/chantal-akerman|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-10-10|first = Jonathan|last = Romney}}</ref> From a young age, Akerman and her mother were exceptionally close, and she encouraged her daughter to pursue a career rather than marry young.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.thejc.com/arts/film/chantal-akerman-my-family-and-other-dark-materials| title = Chantal Akerman: My family and other dark materials| website = www.thejc.com| access-date = 2016-02-27}}</ref>
At age 18, Akerman entered the [[INSAS (film school)|Institut National Supérieur des Arts du Spectacle et des Techniques de Diffusion]], a Belgian [[film school]]. Akerman dropped out during her first term to make the [[short film]] ''Saute ma ville''; she funded the film's costs by trading diamond shares on the [[Antwerp]] [[stock exchange]].<ref name=criterion>{{cite web |last1=Margulies |first1=Ivone |title=A Matter of Time: Jeanne Dielman, 23, quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles |url=http://www.criterion.com/current/posts/1215-a-matter-of-time-jeanne-dielman-23-quai-du-commerce-1080-bruxelles |website=The Criterion Collection |accessdate=18 August 2009}}</ref>
==Family==
Akerman had an extremely close relationship with her mother, captured in some of her films. In 1976 ''[[News From Home]]'', Akerman's mother's letters outlining mundane family activities serve as a soundtrack throughout the film.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Lebow|first1=Alisa|title=Identity Slips: The Autobiographical Register In The Work Of Chantal Akerman|journal=Film Quarterly|date=2016|volume=1|issue=70|pages=54–60}}</ref> The 2015 ''[[No Home Movie]]'' centers on mother-daughter relationships, largely situated in the kitchen, and is a response to her mother's death.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal|last1=Davies|first1=Jon|title=Every Home A Heartache: Chantal Akerman|journal=C: International Contemporary Art|date=2016|issue=130}}</ref> The film explores issues of [[metempsychosis]],<ref name="ReferenceB"/> the last shot of the film acting as a memento mori of the mother's apartment.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Akerman acknowledged that her mother was at the center of her work and admitted to feeling directionless after her death.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The maternal imagery can be found throughout all of Akerman's films, as an homage and an attempt to reconstitute the image and voice of the mother.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> In ''Family In Brussels'', Akerman narrates the story, interchanging her own voice with her mother's.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Work==
===Early work and influences=== Akerman claimed that, at the age of 15, after viewing [[Jean-Luc Godard]]'s ''[[Pierrot le fou]]'' (1965), she decided, that same night, to become a filmmaker. In 1971, Akerman's first short film, ''Saute ma ville'', premiered at the [[International Short Film Festival Oberhausen]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Margulies |first=Ivone |date=1996 |title=Nothing Happens: Chantal Akerman's hyperrealist everyday |location=Durham |publisher=Duke University Press |page=2 |isbn=0-8223-1723-0}}</ref> That year, she moved to [[New York City]], where she remained until 1972.
At [[Anthology Film Archives]] in New York, Akerman was impressed with the work of [[Stan Brakhage]], [[Jonas Mekas]], [[Michael Snow]], [[Yvonne Rainer]], and [[Andy Warhol]].
===Critical recognition=== Her first feature film, [[Hotel Monterey (film)|''Hotel Monterey'']] (1972), and subsequent short films, ''La Chambre 1'' and ''La Chambre 2'', reveal the influence of structural filmmaking through these films' usage of long takes. These protracted shots serve to oscillate images between abstraction and figuration. Akerman's films from this period also signify the start of her collaboration with [[cinematographer]] [[Babette Mangolte]].
In 1973, Akerman returned to Belgium and, in 1974, she received critical recognition for her feature ''[[Je Tu Il Elle|Je, Tu, Il, Elle]] (I, You, He, She)''. Feminist and queer film scholar [[B. Ruby Rich]] noted that ''Je Tu Il Elle'' can be seen as a "cinematic Rosetta Stone of [[Human female sexuality|female sexuality]]".
Akerman's most significant film, ''[[Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles]]'', was released in 1975. Often considered one of the greatest examples of [[feminist]] filmmaking, the film makes a hypnotic, real-time study of a middle-aged widow's stifling routine of domestic chores and prostitution. Upon the film's release, ''[[The New York Times]]'' called ''Jeanne Dielman'' the "first masterpiece of the feminine in the history of the cinema". Chantal Akerman scholar Ivone Margulies says the picture is a filmic paradigm for uniting feminism and anti-illusionism.<ref name="criterion"/> The film was named the 19th greatest film of the 20th century by [[J. Hoberman]] of the ''[[Village Voice]]''.<ref>Hoberman, J. (2001) [4 January 2000]. "100 Best Films of the 20th Century: Village Voice Critics' Poll". The Village Voice (reprint ed.). Reprinted by AMC.</ref>
===Philosophy===
Akerman has acknowledged that her cinematic approach can be explained, in part, through the writings of [[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Felix Guattari]].<ref name="Duke University Press">{{cite book|last1=Marguilles|first1=Ivonne|title=Nothing Happens: Chantal Akerman's Hyperrealist Everyday|date=1996|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham|isbn=9780822317265|page=32}}</ref> [[Deleuze]] and [[Guattari]] write about the concept of minor literature as being characterized by the following things: *1. Minor literature is the literature that a [[minority group|minority]] makes in a major language; the language is effected by a strong co-efficient of [[deterritorialization]]. *2. Every individual matter is immediately plugged into political because minor literature exists in a narrow space. *3. Everything has a collective value: what the solitary writer says already has collective value.<ref name="What Is A Minor Literature">{{cite journal|last1=Deleuze|first1=Gilles|last2=Guattari|first2=Félix|last3=Brinkley|first3=Robert|title=What Is A Minor Literature?|journal=Mississippi Review|date=1983|volume=3|issue=1}}</ref>
[[Deleuze]] and [[Guattari]] claim that these characteristics describe the revolutionary conditions within the canon of literature.<ref name="What Is A Minor Literature"/> Akerman has referenced [[Deleuze]] and [[Guattari]] on how, in minor literature, the characters assume an immediate, nonhierarchical relation between small individual matters and economic, commercial, juridical, and political ones.<ref name="Duke University Press"/> While the filmmaker has an interest in multiple [[deterritorialization]]s, she also considers the feminist demand for the exercise of [[Identity (social science)|identity]], where a borderline status may be an undesirable position.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Marguilles|first1=Ivonne|title=Nothing Happens: Chantal Akerman's Hyperrealist Everyday|date=1996|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham|isbn=9780822317265|page=25}}</ref>
===Feminism===
Akerman has used the setting of a kitchen to explore the intersection between femininity and domesticity.<ref name="New York Times">{{cite news|last1=Donadio|first1=Rachel|title=The Director's Director: Chantal Akerman|publisher=New York Times|date=25 March 2016}}</ref> The kitchens in Akerman's work provide intimate spaces for connection and conversation and serve the function of a backdrop to the dramas of daily life.<ref name="New York Times"/> The kitchens, alongside other domestic spaces, act as self-confining prisons under patriarchal conditions.<ref name="New York Times"/> In Akerman's work, the kitchen acts as a domestic theatre.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Akerman|first1=Chantal|last2=Sultan|first2=Terrie|title=Chantal Akerman: Moving Through Time and Space|date=2008|publisher=Distributed Art Publishers|location=Bluffer Gallery, Art Museum of the University of Houston|page=7}}</ref>
Although Akerman is often grouped within feminist and queer thinking, the filmmaker has articulated her distance from an essentialist feminism.<ref name="Duke University Press"/> Akerman resists labels relating to her identity like "female", "Jewish" and "lesbian", choosing instead to immerse herself in the identity of being a daughter; Akerman has stated that she sees film as a "generative field of freedom from the boundaries of identity".<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The filmmaker has advocated for multiplicity of expression, explaining that "when people say there is a feminist film language, it is like saying there is only one way for women to express themselves".<ref name="Duke University Press"/> The filmmaker asserted that there are as many cinematic languages as there are individuals.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Writer and scholar Ivone Marguiles notes that Akerman's resistance to be categorized is in response to the rigidity of cinema's earlier essentialist realism and "indicates an awareness of the project of a transhistorical and transcultural feminist aesthetics of the cinema".<ref name="Duke University Press"/>
Akerman works with the feminist motto of the personal being political, complicating it by an investigation of representational links between private and public.<ref name="Duke University Press"/> In Jeanne Dielman, Akerman's most well-known film, the main protagonist does not supply a transparent, accurate representation of a fixed social reality.<ref name="Duke University Press"/> Throughout the film, the housewife and prostitute Jeanne is revealed to be a construct, with multiple historical, social, and cinematic resonances.<ref name="Duke University Press"/>
Akerman engages with realist representations, a form which is historically grounded to act as a feminist gesture and simultaneously as an "irritant" to fixed categories of "woman".<ref name="Duke University Press"/>
===Later career=== In 1991, Akerman was a member of the jury at the [[41st Berlin International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/1991/04_jury_1991/04_Jury_1991.html |title=Berlinale: 1991 Juries |work=berlinale.de |accessdate=2011-03-21}}</ref> In 2011, she joined the full-time faculty of the MFA Program in Media Arts Production at the [[City College of New York]] as a distinguished lecturer and the first Michael & Irene Ross Visiting Professor of Film/Video & Jewish Studies.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chantal Akerman feature is tapped for New York Film Festival {{!}} The City College of New York |url=https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/news/chantal-akerman-ny_film-fesrtival |website=www.ccny.cuny.edu |date=18 September 2015}}</ref>
==Exhibitions== Important solo exhibitions of Akerman's work have been held at the Museum for Contemporary Art, Antwerp, Belgium (2012), MIT, Cambridge Massachusetts (2008), the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, Israel (2006); [[Princeton University Art Museum]], Princeton, NJ (2006); and the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]], Paris (2003). Akerman has participated in [[Documenta]] XI (2002) and the [[Venice Biennale]] (2001).
In 2011, a film retrospective of Akerman's work was shown at the Austrian Film Museum.<ref name=gallery>{{cite web |url=http://www.mariangoodman.com/artists/chantal-akerman/ |title=Chantal Akerman |website=Marian Goodman Gallery}}</ref>
The 2015 Venice Biennale included an installation of interspersed parallel screens displaying the landscape-in-motion footage that would appear in "No Home Movie".
In 2018, the [[Jewish Museum (Manhattan)|Jewish Museum]] presented her final video installation ''NOW'' (2015) in the exhibition ''Scenes from the Collection'', and acquired her work for the collection.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thejewishmuseum.org/exhibitions/scenes-from-the-collection|title=Scenes from the Collection|website=The Jewish Museum|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref>
==Cinematography==
Akerman's cinematography is characterized by the dryness of language, the lack of metaphorical associations, the composition in a series of discontinuous blocks, the interest in putting a poor, withered syntax and reduced vocabulary at the service of a new intensity.<ref name="What Is A Minor Literature"/> Many directors have cited Akerman's films as an influence on their work.<ref name="New York Times"/> [[Kelly Reichardt]], [[Gus Van Sant]], and [[Sofia Coppola]] have noted their exploration of filming in real time as a tribute to Akerman.<ref name="New York Times"/>
Terrie Sultan, art historian, claims that Akerman's "narrative is marked by an almost Proustian attention to detail and visual grace".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Akerman|first1=Chantal|last2=Sultan|first2=Terrie|title=Chantal Akerman: Moving Through Time and Space|date=2008|publisher=Distributed Art Publishers|location=Bluffer Gallery, Art Museum of the University of Houston|page=26}}</ref> Similarly, Akerman's visual language resists easy categorization and summarization: the filmmaker creates narrative through filmic syntax instead of plot development.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite book|last1=Akerman|first1=Chantal|last2=David|first2=Catherine|last3=Michael|first3=Tarantino|title=Bordering On Fiction: Chantal Akerman's D'Est|date=1995|publisher=New York: Distribured Art Publishers|location=Minneapolis, Walker Art Center|page=54}}</ref>
Akerman was influenced by European art cinema, as well as structuralist film.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Structuralist film used formalist experimentation to propose a reciprocal relationship between image and viewer.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Akerman cites [[Michael Snow]] as a structuralist inspiration, especially his film Wavelength, which is composed of a single shot of a photograph of a sea on a loft wall, with the camera slowly zooming in.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Akerman was drawn to the perceived dullness of structuralism because it rejected the dominant cinema's concern for plot.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> As a teenager in Brussels, Akerman skipped school in order to see movies, including films from the experimental festival in Knokke-le-Zoute.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Akerman addresses the voyeurism that is always present within cinematic discourse by often playing a character within her films, thus placing herself on both sides of the camera simultaneously.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The filmmaker used the boredom of structuralism in order to generate a bodily feeling in the viewer, accentuating the passage of time.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Akerman's filming style relies on capturing ordinary life. By encouraging viewers to have patience for a slower pace, her films emphasize the humanity of the everyday.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> Kathy Halbreich states that the filmmaker "creates a cinema of waiting, of passages, of resolutions deferred".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Akerman|first1=Chantal|last2=David|first2=Catherine|last3=Michael|first3=Tarantino|title=Bordering On Fiction: Chantal Akerman's D'Est|date=1995|publisher=New York: Distribured Art Publishers|location=Minneapolis, Walker Art Center|page=26}}</ref>
Many of Akerman's films portray the movement of people across distances or their absorption with claustrophobic spaces.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Curator Jon Davies states that Akerman's domestic interiors "conceal gendered labour and violence, secrecy and shame, where traumas both large and small unfold with few, if any witnesses".<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
==Death== Akerman died on 5 October 2015 in Paris; ''[[Le Monde]]'' reported that she committed [[suicide]].<ref name=monde>{{cite news|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/cinema/article/2015/10/06/la-cineaste-chantal-akerman-est-morte_4783566_3476.html|author=Isabelle Regnier|title=La cinéaste Chantal Akerman est morte|publisher=''Le Monde''|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref> She was 65.<ref name=nytobit>{{cite news|last1=Donadio|first1=Rachel|last2=Buckley|first2=Clara|title=Chantal Akerman, Pioneering Belgian Filmmaker, Dies at 65|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/07/arts/chantal-akerman-belgian-filmmaker-dies-65.html?_r=0|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015|publisher=''The New York Times''}}</ref><ref name=liberation>{{cite news|url=http://next.liberation.fr/culture-next/2015/10/06/mort-de-la-cineaste-chantal-akerman_1398190|author=Julien Gester|title=Mort de la cinéaste Chantal Akerman|publisher=''Libération''|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/oct/06/chantal-akerman-pioneering-belgium-film-director-and-theorist-dies-aged-65|author=Catherine Shoard|title=Chantal Akerman, pioneering Belgian film director and theorist, dies aged 65|publisher=''Guardian''|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref> Her last film was the documentary ''[[No Home Movie]]'', a series of conversations with her mother shortly before her mother's death; of the film, she said, "I think if I knew I was going to do this, I wouldn't have dared to do it."<ref name="NYT">{{Citation | last =Rapold | first =Nicolas | title =Chantal Akerman Takes Emotional Path in Film About 'Maman' | publisher =''The New York Times'' | date =5 August 2015 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/arts/international/chantal-akerman-takes-emotional-path-in-film-about-maman.html | accessdate = 24 November 2015}}</ref>
According to Akerman's sister, she had recently been hospitalized for [[Major depressive disorder|depression]], before returning home to Paris ten days prior her death.<ref name=nytobit />

{{For|the method of joining wood and moldings at right angles|Coping (joinery)}}
[[File:Bridge 98, Lancaster Canal - geograph.org.uk - 1773863.jpg|thumb|A bridge on the [[Lancaster Canal]], featuring coping stones linked by large metal "staples" <ref>Brushing °</ref>.]]
'''Coping''' (from ''cope'', Latin ''capa'') consists of the capping or covering of a [[wall]].<ref name=EB1911>{{EB1911|wstitle=Coping|volume=7|page=101|inline=1}}</ref>
A '''splayed''' or '''wedge''' coping slopes in a single direction; a '''saddle''' coping slopes to either side of a central high point.<ref>Ching, Francis D. K. (1995). A Visual Dictionary of Architecture. Van Nostrand Reinhold Company. {{ISBN|0-442-02462-2}}, p. 266.</ref>
A coping may consist of stone (capstone), brick, [[tile]], [[slate]], metal, wood or [[Thatching|thatch]]. In all cases it should be weathered to throw off the water.<ref name=EB1911/>
Various types of copings exist. A diagramatic explanation of [[Copper in architecture#Flashing|copper copings]] is available.<ref>Flashings and copings: Coping covers; http://www.copper.org/applications/architecture/arch_dhb/flashings_copings/coping_covers.html</ref><ref>Flashings and coatings: Counterflashing; http://www.copper.org/applications/architecture/arch_dhb/flashings_copings/counterflashing.html</ref><ref>Flashings and copings: Stepped and chimney flashings</ref>
In [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] work copings appeared plain and flat, and projected over the wall with a [[throating]] to form a drip. In later work a steep slope was given to the weathering (mainly on the outer side), and began at the top with an [[astragal]]; in the [[Decorated Period|Decorated]] style there were two or three sets off; and in the later [[Perpendicular Period]] these assumed a wavy section, and the coping [[molding (decorative)|moulding]]s continued round the sides, as well as at top and bottom, [[Miter joint|mitre]]ing at the angles, as in many of the colleges at [[University of Oxford|Oxford]].<ref name=EB1911/>

{{short description|Painting by Jan van Eyck}} {{featured article}} {{italic title}} [[File:Jan van Eyck - Triptych of Mary and Child, St. Michael, and the Catherine - Google Art Project.jpg|450px|thumb|View of the inner wings. The two outer wings contain an Annunciation scene in grisaille. Oil on oak panel, 1437. [[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister]], Dresden. 33.1cm × 13.6cm; 33.1cm × 27.5cm; 33.1cm × 13.6cm]] [[File:Dresden triptych Catherine and frame 1.jpg|thumb|300px|Detail of the right panel showing St. Catherine and the inner mouldings of the protective frame]]
The '''''Dresden Triptych''''' (or '''''Virgin and Child with St. Michael and St. Catherine and a Donor''''', or '''''Triptych of the Virgin and Child''''') is a very small hinged-[[triptych]] altarpiece by the [[Early Netherlandish painting|Early Netherlandish]] painter [[Jan van Eyck]]. It consists of five individual panel paintings: a central inner panel, and two double-sided wings. It is signed and dated 1437, and in the permanent collection of the [[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister]], Dresden, with the panels still in their original frames. The only extant triptych attributed to van Eyck, and the only non-portrait signed with his personal motto, ''<small>ALC IXH XAN</small>'' ("I Do as I Can").<ref group=a>The words "As I Can" are a play on his name. Their spelling varies between examples, usually translated as ''Als ich can''. See Dhanens (1980), 188, 385</ref> the triptych can be placed at the midpoint of his known works. It echoes a number of the motifs of his earlier works while marking an advancement in his ability in handling depth of space, and establishes iconographic elements of [[Marian art in the Catholic Church|Marian portraiture]] that were to become widespread by the latter half of the 15th century. [[Elisabeth Dhanens]] describes it as "the most charming, delicate and appealing work by Jan van Eyck that has survived".<ref name ="Dhanens246">Dhanens (1980), 246</ref>
The paintings on the two outer wings become visible when the triptych is closed. They show the [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin Mary]] and [[Gabriel|Archangel Gabriel]] in an [[Annunciation]] scene painted in [[grisaille]], which because of their near-monochrome colouring give the impression that the figures are sculpted. The three inner panels are set in an ecclesiastical interior. In the central inner panel Mary is seated and holds the [[Child Jesus|Christ Child]] on her lap. On the left hand wing [[Michael (archangel)|Archangel Michael]] presents a kneeling [[Donor portrait|donor]], while on the right St. [[Catherine of Alexandria]] stands reading a prayer book. The interior panels are outlined with two layers of painted bronze frames, inscribed with mostly Latin lettering. The texts are drawn from a variety of sources, in the central frames from biblical descriptions of the [[Assumption of Mary|assumption]], while the inner wings are lined with fragments of prayers dedicated to saints Michael and Catherine.
The work may have been intended for private devotion, perhaps as a portable altarpiece for a migrant cleric. That the frames are so richly decorated with Latin inscriptions indicates that the donor, whose identity is lost, was highly educated and cultured. Because of a lack of surviving documentary evidence on commissions of 15th century-Northern painting, the identities of donors are often established through evidence gathered by modern art historians. In this work, damaged [[coats of arms]] on the borders of the interior wings have been identified with the [[Giustiniani]] of [[Genoa]] – an influential ''[[Albergo (family)|albergo]]'' active from 1362 – who established trade links with [[Bruges]] as early as the mid-14th century.
==Provenance and attribution== The ''Dresden Triptych'' was probably in the possession of the Giustiniani family in the mid- to late-15th century.<ref name ="Dhanens246"/> It is mentioned in a May 10, 1597 record of a purchase by [[Vincenzo Gonzaga, Duke of Mantua]], and was then sold with the Gonzaga Collection to [[Charles I of England]] in 1627.<ref name="Streeton" /> After Charles's fall and execution, the painting went to Paris and was owned by [[Eberhard Jabach]], the [[Cologne]]-based banker and art dealer for [[Louis XIV]] and [[Cardinal Mazarin]]. A year after Jabach's death in 1695, it passed to the [[Elector of Saxony]], and next appears in a 1754 inventory of the [[Gemäldegalerie Alte Meister|Dresden Collection]], attributed to [[Albrecht Dürer]],<ref name ="Dhanens246"/> until the German historian [[Aloys Hirt]] in 1830 established it as a van Eyck.<ref name="Streeton" /> In the mid-19th century the Dresden catalogues first attribute it to [[Hubert van Eyck]] (d. 1426) and a few years later to Jan.<ref name ="Dhanens246"/>
[[File:Jan van Eyck - Lucca Madonna - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|Jan van Eyck's ''[[Lucca Madonna (van Eyck)|Lucca Madonna]]'', c. 1436. [[Städelsches Kunstinstitut]], Frankfurt]] Van Eyck signed, dated and added his motto to the central panel, a fact only discovered when the frame was removed in the course of a mid-20th century restoration,<ref name="Pächt83"/> and confirmed with the 1959 discovery of the signature which is placed along with the words ''<small>IOHANNIS DE EYCK ME FECIT ET C[OM]PLEVIT ANNO D[OMINI MCCCCXXXVII.ALC IXH XAN</small>'' ("Jan Van Eyck Made And Completed Me In The Year 1437. As I Can"). The word "completed" (''complevit'') may suggest the completion date, but as master painters of the era typically had workshops to assist on major works, the wording can be seen as aggressively socially ambitious; perhaps an arrogant master painter indicating his workshop assistants had little material involvement in the panels, and that he was primarily responsible for its design and execution. This view is reinforced by the fact that it is the only non-portrait to contain van Eyck's motto, ''<small>ALC IXH XAN</small>''.<ref name="b60" /> Until the discovery of the signature the piece was variously dated to an early piece from the 1420s to his later period in the late 1430s.<ref name = "Dhanens242"/> Because the panels are so definitely attributed they are often used as a touchstone to date van Eyck's other works; there are a number of evident stylistic developments, including the type of stained glass windows and mouldings around the [[Arcade (architecture)|arcades]], and his ability at handling [[Perspective (graphical)|perspective]], which can be used to determine if other works at least pre-date the triptych.<ref name="h152">Harbison (1991), 152</ref>
The central panel has often been compared to his unsigned and undated ''[[Lucca Madonna (van Eyck)|Lucca Madonna]]'' of c. 1436. That work echoes the central panel of the Dresden triptych in a number of aspects, including the dark green canopy, the figuration and positioning of Mary, her heavily-folded dress, the orange and brown pigments of the floor, the geometric carpet and the wooden carvings.<ref name="h106" /> The ''Lucca Madonna'' is thought to be a portrait of the artist's much younger wife, [[Portrait of Margaret van Eyck|Margaret]].<ref>Harbison (1991), 97</ref>
==Description== The work measures {{convert|33|×|27.5|cm|in}} including the frames.<ref name="Streeton" /> Given this miniaturist scale, the triptych probably functioned as a portable devotional piece, or ''altare portabile''.<ref name="h61"/> Members of the upper-classes and nobility acquired these through papal dispensation,<ref name="Streeton" /> to use during travel and typically during pilgrimage. Van Eyck's patron and employer [[Philip the Good]] owned at least one portable triptych of which fragments survive.<ref name ="Luber30">Luber (1998), 30</ref>
The three inner panels comprise a typical ''[[Sacred conversation|sacra conversazione]]'', a form established in Italy in the latter half of the 14th century with a [[patron saint]] presenting the donor, usually kneeling, to an enthroned "Deity or Mother of God".<ref name ="Pächt81">Pächt (1999), 81</ref> John Ward believes the rich and complex [[iconography]] and symbolic meaning van Eyck employed in his religious panels served to highlight the co-existence the artist saw between the spiritual and material worlds. In his earlier paintings, subtle iconographical features – referred to as disguised symbolism – are typically woven into the work, as "relatively small, in the background, or in the shadow [details]".<ref name="W11">Ward (1994), 11</ref> These elements include the apparition of the Virgin before the donor, whose panel contains carvings that seem to be reflective of events of his life.<ref name="W11"/> In his religious panels after 1436, van Eyck's reliance on iconographical or symbolic elements is greatly reduced. Ward speculates the reduced size of the work or the wishes of the commissioner influenced this choice, or he "decided that he had exhausted the most interesting possibilities and .... much of his carefully planned symbolism went unappreciated by patrons or by viewers."<ref>Ward (1994), 13</ref> According to Jacobs, the work reflects a system of symbolism in so far as heavenly and earthly objects are juxtaposed. This is most evident in the disparity between the monochromatic exterior and vivid inner panels.<ref name="Jacobs 2012 80">Jacobs (2012), 80</ref>
===Frames===
The triptych retains its original frames, which are both ornate and served to protect the piece from the effects of light and smoke during travel and when ''in situ''.<ref name="n239">Nash (2008), 239</ref> The inner frames have recessed mouldings and are carved with gilded inscriptions,<ref name="Streeton" /> and the top corners of the two wing panels each bear a carved set of [[coat of arms]].<ref name = "Dhanens242"/> The lettering and phrases in Latin serve a dual purpose. They are decorative, similar to margins in medieval manuscripts, and set the context for the imagery; van Eyck would have expected the viewer to contemplate text and imagery in unison.<ref name="s146">Smith (2004), 146</ref> Writing about Early Netherlandish triptychs, Jacobs says the inscriptions serve to distinguish and separate between the worldly and spiritual spheres, with the panels showing earthly images while the inscriptions on the frames act as reminder of heavenly influence. The letterings reinforce the duality between the earthly and heavenly, with St. Catherine's a reminder of ascetic piety while the figure herself is depicted in sumptuous garments and jewels.<ref>Jacobs (2012), 83</ref>
The inscriptions on the central panel are fragments from the [[Book of Wisdom]] (7:26 and 7:29), and [[Ecclesiastes]] (24: 23–24).<ref name ="Dhanens385">Dhanens (1980), 385</ref><ref group=a>The lettering on that panel reads: <small>''HEC EST SPECIOSIOR SOLE ET SUPER OMNEM DISPOSTITIONEM STELLARUM LUCI COMPARATA INVENITUR PRIOR. CANDOR EST ENIM LUCIS AETERNAE ET SPECULUM SINE MACULA DEI MAIESTATIS ECT. EGO QUASI VITIS FRUCTIVICAVI SUAVITATEM ODORIS ET FLORES MEI FRUCTIS HONORIS ET HONESTATIS. ECO MATER PULCHARAE DILECTIONIS ET TIMORIS ET MAGNITUDINES ET SANCTAE SPEI''</small> ("She is more beautiful than the sun and above the whole order of the stars. Being compared with the light of day, she is found to excel. For she is the brightness of eternal light, and the flawless mirror of God's majesty. As a vine I have brought forth a pleasant fragrance, and my flowers are the fruit of honour and probity. I am the mother of fair love, and of fear, and of greatness, and of holy hope"). see Dhanens (1980), 385; Heath (2008), 110</ref> Those on the wing panels are taken from texts referring directly to the two saints.<ref name="Streeton" />
===Inner panels===
====Virgin and Child==== In the central panel the Virgin and Child are enthroned in a church [[nave]] within a columned [[basilica]] running on either side.<ref name="h106">Heath (2008), 106</ref> The columns are painted using a variety of dark red, orange and grey pigments, a colour scheme which Peter Heath describes as lending to a "sense of airy silence".<ref name="h107">Heath (2008), 107</ref> The throne is positioned on a [[dais]], before a lavishly detailed [[Oriental carpets in Renaissance painting|oriental carpet]] lying on a similarly geometrically designed tiled floor.<ref name="h106" /> The arms of the canopied throne and the arches to either side contain carved or sculptured figures, including tiny representations of [[Isaac]], and [[David and Goliath]],<ref>Dhanens (1980), 248</ref> although art historian Antje Maria Neuner reads this carving as showing [[Jephthah]] sacrificing his daughter.<ref name="h107" /> Mary wears a richly embroidered and as is typical for van Eyck, voluminous red robe, which effectively serves as a [[Baldachin|cloth of honour]].<ref>Purtle, Carol J. Review of "The Marian Paintings of Jan van Eyck", by Goodgal, Dana. ''Renaissance Quarterly'', Volume 36, No. 4, Winter, 1983. 590–594</ref> The robe is placed over a blue square-cut underdress edged with a jewelled border.<ref name= "Weale29"/> In van Eyck's Marian paintings, he almost always clothes her in red writes Pächt, which makes her seem to dominate the space.<ref name ="Pächt84"/> The Christ Child is naked and holds towards the donor a [[banderole]]<ref name="h106" /> adorned with a phrase from the [[Gospel of Matthew]] (11:29), ''<small>DISCITE A ME, QUIA MITIS SUM ET HUMILIS CORDE</small>'' ("Learn of me, for I am meek and lowly in heart").<ref name="b60" />
[[File:Jan van Eyck - Triptych of Mary and Child, St. Michael, and the Catherine - Google Art Project Crop.jpg|thumb|310px|Detail showing the Virgin and Child sitting on the canopied throne with multi-coloured marble columns to the left]] Mary's presence in the church is symbolic; she and the child occupy the area where the altar would normally be situated.<ref name="b56">Borchert (2008), 56</ref> Like van Eyck's two other late Madonna portraits (''[[Virgin and Child with Canon van der Paele]]'' of 1436 and ''[[Madonna in the Church]]'' of c. 1438–40), Mary is unrealistically large and out of proportion to her surroundings. This reflects the influence of 12th- and 13th-century Italian artists such as [[Cimabue]] and [[Giotto]], who in turn drew on the tradition of monumental depictions of Mary from [[Byzantine art|Byzantine]] icons. According to [[Lorne Campbell (art historian)|Lorne Campbell]], Mary is presented as if about to "rise from her throne and advance into the same plane as St. Michael and St. Catherine, she would tower above them and also above the columns of the church."<ref name="C23" /> This idea is in keeping with van Eyck's tendency in such portraits to present Mary as if she was an apparition materialising before the donor in response to his prayer and devotion.<ref>Nash (2008), 283</ref> Van Eyck's Mary is here monumental, but less overwhelmingly large than in 13th century works. She is disproportionate to the architecture in her panel, but approximately proportional to the figures in the wings. This restraint evidences the beginning of van Eyck's mature phase, most evidently seen in the composition's "greater spatial depth".<ref name ="Pächt82">Pächt (1999), 82</ref>
Christ's pose closely follows that of the ''Paele Madonna''; his body still leans towards the donor but here his head faces the viewer more directly.<ref name ="Pächt84">Pächt (1999), 84</ref>
====Saints and donor wings==== [[Catherine of Alexandria|St. Catherine]] and the [[Michael (archangel)|Archangel Michael]] occupy the right and left hand panels respectively. They appear to stand in either the aisles<ref name="C23">Campbell (2004), 23</ref> or [[Ambulatory|ambulatories]],<ref name="Streeton" /> and a few bays to the fore compared to the central panel.<ref name="h106" /> Their depictions are in keeping with the artist's evolving style: the aisles convey spaciousness, especially by the implied spaces out of view, while both saints subtly lean close to Mary. The use of perspective makes the saints appear small; according to Pächt they are "less solid than the massive figures in the ''Paele Madonna''. It was this Gothic daintiness that led many scholars ... to place this among Jan van Eyck's early work".<ref name ="Pächt83">Pächt (1999), 83</ref> The two side panels are filled with light streaming through the windows that reflects off the saints' accoutrements, glinting from St. Michael's armour and St. Catherine's bejewelled steel sword.<ref name="h107"/>
[[File:Jan van Eyck Dresden Catherine.jpg|thumb|200px|Detail showing a crowned [[Catherine of Alexandria|St. Catherine]]. She can be identified through the various [[hagiography|hagiographical]] objects around her.]] On the right panel St. Catherine is presented as almost the essence of a gothic princess. She stands reading a book in "ravishing modesty",<ref name ="Dhanens246"/> with unbound blonde hair, which is topped with an elaborate jewelled crown very similar to that in the ''[[Madonna of Chancellor Rolin]]'', combined with her rich blue gown and [[tabard]] of white draped [[Ermine (heraldry)|ermine]] showing her as the princess she was. A golden chain with a jewelled pendant hangs from her neck. The attributes associated with her are included in her depiction. In her right hand, she holds the sword used for her beheading and at her feet lies the [[breaking wheel]] on which she was tortured.<ref name = "D250">Dhanens (1980), 250</ref> Like the woman in van Eyck's ''[[Arnolfini Portrait]]'' she is "fashionably pear-shaped"; Heath describes her attire as "more dazzling than the Virgin's", mirroring St. Michael's splendid armour on the opposite panel.<ref name="h112">Heath (2008), 112</ref>
St. Catherine's presence can be attributed to a number of factors. At that period her reputation and popularity were second to Mary's; she was both an educated and outspoken woman during her lifetime – characteristics that perhaps mirrored the donor's. She is absorbed in her book in a contemplative manner, which might be reflective of a donor with a similar temperament.<ref name="h110" /> The frame of her wing is inscribed with the words <small>''VIRGO PRUDENS ANELAVIT, GRANUM SIBI RESERVAVIT, VENTILANDO PALEAM. DISIPLINUS EST IMBUTA PUELLA COELESTIBUS, NUDA NUDUM EST SECUTA CHRISTUM PASSIBUS, DUM MUNDANIS EST EXUTA ECT''</small> ("The prudent virgin has longed for the starry throne where she has made her place ready; leaving the world's threshing floor, she saved the grain for herself by winnowing the chaff. The young girl has been steeped in heavenly learning. Stripped of everything, with sure footsteps she followed Christ until she was delivered from earthly affairs").<ref name="h112"/><ref name="Dhanens 1980 368"/>
[[File:Dresden Triptych Detail Archangel Michael with Donor 1.jpeg|thumb|left|240px|Detail of the Archangel Michael presenting the donor. Note the two faux bronze painted frames.]] A landscape can be seen through the window behind St. Catherine. Because of the miniature scale of the painting it can be seen only at close up. The view is built with extremely fine brushwork and shows a number of highly detailed buildings<ref name="b60">Borchert (2008), 60</ref> and hills before snowcapped mountains.<ref name="h112"/>
A lance rests against the shoulder of a youthful-looking St. Michael.</small><ref name="Dhanens 1980 368">Dhanens (1980), 368</ref> Michael is dressed in elaborately jewelled and coloured armour, his left arm holding his helmet,<ref name= "Weale29">Weale (1903), 29</ref> while his right hand rests on the shoulder of the donor as he is presented to Mary. The donor kneels in prayer before the Virgin, with his hands held upwards [[Orans|as if in prayer]], although they are not clasped. He wears a gold ring on his right small finger,<ref name="h107" /> and is dressed in a long olive-green [[houppelande]],<ref name="Streeton" /> at the time the height of fashion and an indicator of status within the [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundian court]].<ref name="h61"/> The gown has a fur-lined high collar and deep baggy sleeves, also lined with fur. The donor's bowl-shaped haircut, rounded at the fringe but cut above his ears, is also typical of mid-1430s Netherlandish fashion. Except for the red hood, the garment closely resembles that worn by the groom in the ''Arnolfini Portrait''.<ref name = "D248ff"/>
The [[Capital (architecture)|capital]] of the pillar above the donor's head is lined with carvings of military scenes. Similar carvings are seen near the donor in van Eyck's earlier ''van der Paele'' and ''Madonna of Chancellor Rolin'',<ref name = "D248ff"/> and where they depict events or personal circumstances from the donor's life. Those in the present work likely serve a similar role, however because the donor is unidentified it is unknown as to what they may refer.<ref>Teasdale-Smith (1981), 274</ref> [[Elisabeth Dhanens]] speculates that they might depict the [[sarcophagus]] of [[Hippolytus of Rome|Hippolytus]] in [[Pisa]], which she believes adds credibility to the belief the donor was of Italian origin; she also notes the military scene reflects St. Michael's status as military commander.<ref name = "D248ff">Dhanens (1980), 248–249</ref> Ward compares the carving to a similar one found in the Washington ''[[Annunciation (van Eyck, Washington)|Annunciation]]''.<ref name = "Ward209"/> Unlike in van Eyck's earlier votive portraits the donor is positioned at a remove from the Marian apparition, and at a much smaller scale to Mary on a triptych wing.<ref name="h61">Harbison (1991), 61</ref>
The lettering running along the edges of the panel's frame consists of a prayer fragment from the liturgy for the [[Michaelmas|feast of St. Michael]]. The extract reads ''<small>HIC EST ARCHANGELUS PRINCEPS MILITAE ANGELORUM CUIUS HONOR PRAESTAT BENEFICIA POPULORUM ET ORATARIO PERDUCIT AD REGNA COELORUM. HIC ANGELUS MICHAEL DEI NUNTIUS DE ANIMABUS JUSTIS. GRATIA DEI ILLE VICTOR IN COELIS RESEDIT. A PACIBUS</small>'' ("This is Michael the Archangel, leader of the angelic hosts, whose privilege it is to grant favours to the people, and whose prayer leads them to the Kingdom of Heaven. The Archangel Michael is God's messenger for the souls of the just. By the grace of God, that great victor has taken his place in Heaven, on the side of peace'").<ref name="h110">Heath (2008), 110</ref> {{clear}}
===Outer panels=== [[File:Jan van Eyck - Small Triptych (outer panels) - WGA07615.jpg|240px|left|thumb|The closed view shows an ''Annunciation'', with imitation statues of the [[Gabriel|Archangel Gabriel]] and Mary.]] When the triptych is closed, the outer wings reveal an [[Annunciation]] scene with the [[Archangel Gabriel]] and Mary painted in [[grisaille]]. The figures form an [[Illusionism (art)|illusionistic]] imitation of sculpture, a conceit which van Eyck extends by placing them on octagonal pedestals.<ref name="b60" /> The figures are illuminated by light from the left, a device van Eyck often used to imply the presence of God. A dove, representing the [[Holy Spirit]], hovers above Mary. Because the dove is also in grisaille but not attached to a pedestal and apparently floating unfixed above the saints, its presence serves to highlight that the viewer is not looking at sculpture but at a painted representation of sculpture.<ref>Jacobs (2012), 63</ref>
The annunciation dominates any other theme on the outer wings of Northern 15th-century [[polyptych]]s. The tradition originates from Byzantine art, with van Eyck largely responsible for re-popularising the practice.<ref name="j64">Jacobs (2012) 64</ref> Along with his ''[[Ghent Altarpiece]]'', the ''Dresden Triptych'' is one of the earliest surviving examples of the technique, and on this basis he is usually credited as the innovator of a motif that became almost standard from the mid-15th century.<ref>Jacobs (2012), 63–64</ref> As the annunciation marks the incarnation of Christ, its representation on the outer wings gives symmetry to the scenes of his life typically detailed on the inner panels.<ref name="h55">Harbison (1995), 55</ref>
[[File:Hugo van der goes portinari triptych closed.jpg|thumb|320px|Outer wings of [[Hugo van der Goes]]'s ''[[Portinari Altarpiece]]'', c. 1475. [[Galleria degli Uffizi]], Florence. Van der Goes closely follows the convention established by van Eyck, although he omits the octagonal pedestals typical of actual sculpture.<ref name="h55"/>]] The outer wings of 15th-century [[diptych]]s and triptychs typically contained Annunciation scenes painted in grisaille. Molly Teasdale Smith believes the practice echoes the tradition of covering religious imagery with grey cloth during the then-46-day [[lent]]en period leading up to Easter. There is a symmetry with this in how polyptychs were typically kept closed except for Sundays or church holidays, when they were opened to reveal the more colourful and expansive inner panels.<ref name="h54-5">Harbison (1995), 54–55</ref>
According to Dhanens, the sculptural depictions on the outer panels are a "brilliant success ... in imparting a sense of life to the supposed statues."<ref name = "D251"/> The wings continue van Eyck's innovation in placing two grisaille outer panels wings of polyptychs; the earliest extant example being the Annunciation wings of the ''Ghent Altarpiece''.<ref name = "Ward209">Ward (1975), 209</ref>
==Architecture== The depicted church is of a [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] style with [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] elements. There are pointed [[Canopy (building)|canopies]] above Mary, and the nave is narrow, barely wide enough to contain her. It is walled by a [[colonnade]] joined by [[entablature]]s and capped with rounded arches.<ref name="h151" /> The columns are variously of pink, red and purple marble. Each of the capitals is decorated with faux carvings, some showing representations of the twelve [[Apostle (Christian)|apostles]] under a small [[baldachin]]. The [[Vault (architecture)|vaulting]] is visible in the aisles but not in the central nave.<ref name = "D248ff"/> There are a number of implied spaces not visible to the viewer. The central panel contains two on either side of the pillars, others lead from the balcony above the throne, and there are unseen exits to hallways at the rear of the two wing panels.<ref name="h151">Harbison (1991), 151</ref> The east facing windows in the right hand wing resemble those in van Eyck's ''[[Rolin Madonna]]''.<ref name = "D248ff"/>
The centre panel's spatial depth marks an advancement in van Eyck's technique, especially when compared to his similar 1436 ''{{plain link|http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jan_van_Eyck_054-096.jpg|Diptych of the Annunciation}}'' or ''van der Paele'' panel, both of which are comparatively flat. The depth of space is accomplished through such devices as placing the Virgin at the far end of the pictorial space, making her appear both smaller and seemingly at a remove and accentuating the receding lines of the carpets by setting them against the parallels of the folds of her gown.<ref name="Pächt83" /> The recessional perspective is further achieved by the sequence of columns stretching back from the throne.<ref name="h106"/> This is particularly noticeable with the positioning of the throne in comparison to the ''Lucca Madonna'' and van der Paele panels.<ref name = "D248ff"/>
As with van Eyck's earlier paintings of interiors, the building is not based on a particular place, but is an imagined and idealised formation of what he viewed as a perfect and representational architectural space. This is evidenced by a number of features that would be unlikely in an actual contemporary church such as the sculptures that were more secular in nature. In detailing the structure he pays close attention to contemporary models, which he possibly combined with elements from ancient buildings. The columns contain "high [[Prism (geometry)|prismatic]] bases" found in early churches and on the [[Arch of Constantine]].<ref>Wood, Christopher. ''Forgery, Replica, Fiction: Temporalities of German Renaissance Art''. University of Chicago Press, 2008. 195–96. {{ISBN|0-226-90597-7}}</ref> [[Craig Harbison]] believes that because the interior is not based on an actual building, the viewer is not burdened by preconceptions, a device which perhaps opens up the painting's "physiological" impact. In his view, the panels capture the moment when the donor's prayer and piety is rewarded by an apparition of the Virgin and Child. The novelty and unworldliness of the situation is highlighted by the unrealistic size of the Virgin compared to her surroundings.<ref name="h151" />
Light plays a central role in all panels, to an extent almost comparable to van Eyck's ''Madonna in the Church''. The arches and columns are bathed in daylight, echoed by the text of the inscriptions around the central frame allude to light and illumination.<ref name = "D251">Dhanens (1980), 252</ref> Van Eyck pays close attention to the saturating effects and gradations of the light, which enters from the left and spreads across the middle ranges of each panel. He often used light to indicate a divine ethereal presence.<ref>Smith (2003), 63</ref> Because the implied spaces found on either side of Mary and leading into each of the wing panels are bathed in this light, they can be seen as conduits for the divine.<ref name="h151" />
The triptych influenced [[Rogier van der Weyden]]'s 1445–50 ''[[Seven Sacraments Altarpiece]]'' in a number of aspects, most obviously in its disregard of scale, especially with Mary's size relative to the other figures and surrounding architecture. Van der Weyden develops the idea further, placing a large crucifixion towering above the figures and almost spanning the height of the central panel.<ref name="C23" />
== Donor == [[File:Dresden Triptych Detail Donor.jpg|thumb|left|240px|Detail showing the donor. Unusually his hands are held up but unclasped, suggesting that he is caught in wonder rather than prayer.<ref>Dhanens (1980), 249</ref>]]
The identity of the [[Donor portrait|donor]] has not been established, although a number of suggestions have been advanced over the last 200 years. Harbison suggests the work's small scale indicates that it functioned as a portable altarpiece rather than as a private devotional work, and thus was commissioned by or for a member of the clergy.<ref name="h61"/> Other art historians have argued that the donor may have been a [[Genoa|Genoese]] merchant.<ref name="Streeton"/> This belief has been fed by the triptych's similarity to [[Giovanni Mazone]]'s ''Virgin and Child'' altarpiece in [[Pontremoli]], [[Tuscany]], which may place it in the Italian region of [[Liguria]] at latest by the end of the 15th century.<ref name="h61" /> Damaged coats of arms on the inner frames<ref name="Streeton">Streeton, Noëlle L.W. "[http://www.jhna.org/index.php/past-issues/vol-3-1/136-janvaneycksdresden Jan van Eyck's Dresden Triptych: new evidence for the Giustiniani of Genoa in the Borromei ledger for Bruges, 1438]". ''Journal of Historians of Netherlandish Art'', Volume 3, Issue 1, 2011.</ref> have been linked to the Giustiniani family,<!--linked (!) on what basis--> known for establishing trade links with Bruges in the 14th and 15th centuries.<ref name="h61" /> If not commissioned by that family, historical record place the work at least in their possession by the end of the century.<ref name = "Dhanens245"/> In the early 1800s, Frances Weale attempted to place Michele Giustiniani as the donor,<ref name= "Weale29"/> however later historical research has been unable to verify his presence in Bruges around 1437, and he seems to have returned to Italy by 1430.<ref name="Streeton"/>
Mid-twentieth century technical examination revealed the Giustiniani coats of arms may have been painted over an earlier heraldic design, perhaps as early as the 15th century, whose signifiance and history is now lost.<ref name = "Dhanens242"/> Dhanens theorises that a member of the Giustiniani family may have established other associations with St. Michael and St. Catherine, advancing that they were a member of the Italian Rapondi family,<ref group=a>The Rapondis had strong banking ties to the Burgundian dukes and were active in Paris and the Low Countries. See Small, Graham. "The City, the Duke and Their Banker: The Rapondi Family and the Formation of the Burgundian State (1384–1430)". ''The Economic History Review''. Volume 60, No. 3 (Aug., 2007), 626–627</ref> whose trading house in Paris was named after St. Catherine. Their daughter, also named Catherine, married the Italian merchant Michel Burlamacchi (Bollemard in Flemish) from [[Lucca]], who was active in Bruges. From this Dhanens theorises the piece was commissioned as a wedding gift for the couple. Documents show weavers in [[Wervik]] paid taxes to Catherine Rapondi and in September 1434, when Michele Burlamacchi was tax collector in that town, van Eyck received a [[stipend]] funded by local tax receipts, suggesting a connection. Dhanens admits the donor's identity is lost, but she says of the piece that "it could have been a gift from the husband to the wife, a pledge of his affection during his absences; or it could have been a gift from the wife to the husband, by way of protection on his travels."<ref name = "Dhanens245">Dhanens (1980), 245</ref> {{clear}}
==Condition== The triptych is in poor condition, having suffered damage and heavy paint loss, and has undergone a number of restorations.<ref name="c139">Campbell (2006), 139</ref> The outer wooden frames, originally painted in grey and yellow marbling, were later overpainted in a design of black and red<ref name="Jacobs 2012 80" /> in the 16th or 17th centuries when "a faux turtle-shell design, imitating the then-fashionable veneer, replaced the earlier scheme of jaspered paint".<ref name="Streeton" /> An ebony surround was added to the inner frames for protection in the 1840s.<ref name="Streeton" /> There has been extensive repair work on the paint forming Mary's dress,<ref name="b60" /> with large areas of her gown repaired in 1844 by painter [[Eduard Bendemann]].<ref name="c139" /><!-- was there only one restoration in the 1840s w/ conflicting dates in sources? --> The badly damaged coats of arms have been retouched,<ref name = "Dhanens242">Dhanens (1980), 242</ref> while the frames have sustained impairment and are overpainted in areas.<ref name="h61"/> The painting was taken to Moscow after the Second World War. It was returned in 1959 after it had been cleaned, restored and underwent examination in a laboratory. This process revealed the ''<small>ALC IXH XAN</small>'' inscription on the inner moulding of the central frame in front of the tiled floor when a coat of brown paint was stripped away.<ref name="Streeton" /><ref name = "Dhanens242"/> The surround was removed during the 1959 restoration.<ref name="Streeton"/>
